Edit 2: I found out a proof: You have the set of every possible direction to project the points. This set has infinitely many elements. To get the set of the "allowed" projections, you have to subtract the set of those projections, where any of the points and up on eachother. Take a look at every pair of points. Every pair defines a direction, that is not allowed. So buy collecting all of these directions we have a set of not allowed directions, subtract it from the original set. I'm gonna stop before any kind of explanation is given based on what's here in the video. In as non-rigorous of a way as possible, I'll see if I can come up with a proof. This is a sort of "forest for the trees" problem if allowed to approach infinity, but it is finite; there is "light" that all points can see that allows the rotation of the line l to change from one pivot to another without conflict (as would exist in a colinear set). Since line l must rotate in a consistent direction, and no more than three points are colinear, l can only change pivot from one point in set S (some Sx, where x is an arbitrary indicator of position) to another. The set S contains points S0, S1, S2... up to Sn, the last point in the set. Given the consistent direction of rotation of line l on any point in set S, there exists a cyclical (like a deck of cards) sequential set of points in the rotation around any given point Sx that includes all other points in set S (set S-Sx). Because this sequential set S-Sx is unique to each point Sx and Sx is colinear with only one other point at a time, the point that follows in the rotation after a change in pivot point cannot be the previous pivot point. Because set S-Sx includes every other point in set S and the point that follows Sx in the pivot point in the sequence cannot pivot immediately to Sx (in any set with 3 or more points), the pivot must change to another point in the set S following the sequences of each point's rotations. Due to these being unique, cyclical sequences, the overarching cyclical sequence set must be a composition of each of the sequences S-S0 through S-Sn (sequence set So(S0-Sn)), which includes every point in the set S. This finite sequence is the rotation pattern that line l must follow, based on the rules of its rotation provided earlier. Because line l rotates infinitely many times, following a pivot change along the finite sequence So(S0-Sn), which includes all points in the set S, it must therefore cycle through every point infinitely many times.

Whenever rotation brought a point on the π,3π/2 axis it would replace the previous point in the origin and the coordinates of the other points would change accordingly, thus by using complicated calculus, which I am not proficient in, I would prove that for n number of points the system would run through all possible(infinite) arrangements at least once. Perhaps I would use the fact that there's a finite and smaller subset of S containing all the triangles with the previous, current and succeeding pivot point at their corners...

Then I read the wording of the problem again looking for some helpful hint and realised there's much simpler solutions hinted at by the loose parameters given on the properties of S, other than collinearity.

With that in mind, any point arranged in a straight line along the horizontal axis would prove a deceptively easy solution. But there was the issue of collinearity. A hack of sorts might have been to introduce a small plus or minus deviation on the vertical axis.

Then, I thought what if the points were arranged in a way that traced the graph of the sine or cosine function but that would only do if the line "l" was of finite length, which again isn't specifically clarified. Finally, any of n number of points that traced a circle of radius r could serve as the launching point for the infinite windmill, with both collinearity holding for n to infinity number of points and a line "l" of either finite or infinite length.

Basically it all comes down to proving that tangent line on any point on the circumference of the circle, when rotating, can intersect any two non consecutive points on the circumference of the circle at the same angle, between the tangent and the vertical running through the centre of the circle, as any two consecutive points, which follows from the definition of a tangent line and a circle itself.

1. If the axis of rotation of the line ends up tracing a polygon in the given points, any point inside a cyclic polygon would remain untouched, hence the area of the cyclic polygon should tend to zero, therefore the initial pivot should be as close to the "middle " of the scatter of points. This "Middle" I tried to define as if graph was drawn such that the x and y axis were drawn in a way that all the points in S fall in quadrant 1, the point that is closest to (ymean and xmean) of all points should be chosen as the pivot. To visualize it take any randome scatter plot of graphs. Connect the outermost points into a polygon, then connect the ones inside, then inside those until the centre ones remain. Picking one of those would generally satisfy our original condition.

2. At any point, if the line touches a point in such a way that it shifts into a polygon and remains so. This would happen if the distribution of the dots is such that some are very far away and off to the side and there are some clusters here and there. In such a situation, reverting to our original graph, one might analyze the mean, media and mode and the point closest to the place where all 3 of them tend to converge would give you a "good" starting position.

Note that, "the number or blue points and brown points remain the same" does not hod true for true for ANY position that has been selected such that the intitial distribution of dots is equal on either side. The point is that the distribution of said dots must remain fairly equal on eother side of the line in ALL orientations of the line one could have at that point. The point is that if you select a pivot on the outside, certain points Will not change colour. The "bottom" part of the line, if there is any such thing of a rotating line, would only touch those points that are outside the polygon traced by the line. Therefore, I Find simply saying "the dots on either side should be equal slightly lacking because that might be problematic in certain kinds of distributions.

Ergo, it is not about the points on sides of the line but "inside" and "outside" the path traced by its axis. Therefore the path should be such that at least each point falls outside the plygon atleast once. Now how on earth is that possible?

Lets try an exercise. take five points. start on the edge and start the pivot. The next point it hits, draw a line from the initial point to the second one. When it hits a third point draw a line joining the second and the 3rd. bAsically join n-1th point to the nth point it touches and dont stop when it reaches the first point. This is the path of the axis of rotaion. Do a few rounds. When you start on the outside, it forms a neat little polygon. Now take the same points and pick a point to the middle - you will notice that the line will (cut through/slice through) the neat shape of the polygon at certain places and form a shape like the arm of a star (or a complex polygon) The actual idea is that the line should cut through the polygon and form a star shape continuously. I don't know the mathematics of this, but it seems like sometimes, you can get the dots divided into two separate polygons and the line might stick to one side after cover the other one only once. Therefore, the more "cuts" you have in the polygon the more "complex" a polygon is, the better chances of the required condition being satisfied. In other words, the line should continue to cut through the potential polygons that can otherwise potentially trap it in a cyclical motion. The more such points are, the better the chances of the requirement being fulfilled.

And we find that the probability of that happening is the highest when the point is chosen is closer to the mean, median and mode of the points. Imagine it iike this. Let this point be O. And let us draw concentric circles around O. The dots that fall in the smallest circle have the highest probability of satisfying the condition. The points on the outer circles, are less likely to do so. Note, there will be some set of dots where they might satisfy the conditions but the probabiblity would continue to decrease as we move outwards.

Another way of thiking about this is - when you watch the line rotate through many cycles, you will notice that there are points that it traverses more frequently than others. There's a slightly different way to prove it, a bit longer, but I think it offers a deeper insight.

We note that, chosen an angle, the partition of points that happens with a line through a point at the said angle, is exclusive to that point.
In other words, at every moment (at every angle), no other point expect the pivot could produce the partition.
Hence if a point is just able to replicate the starting partition of the windmill, it will eventually be a pivot!

Pivots are all those points that for some ranges of angles produce the (invariant) partition defined at the beginning of the windmill.

So, our question: is there a partition that is guaranted to be feasible for all the point?
Yes, the "halve partition". (180° rotation is the key to see why)

From this reasoning we have a better view of the "phenomenon". In order to touch all the points we have to listen to the weakest one and choose a partition that it can produce.

Now choose a point to begin with and rotate the sphere as if that point were a pole. As a pole, it would have infinite planes that run through it that bisect the sphere. Chose a plane or line of longitude that makes sure half the points are on one side and half on the other (assuming odd number of points). Now rotate the sphere until another point lines up on that line of longitude. Now switch, make the new point the pole and continue rotating in the same direction. This new pole also has infinite lines of longitude running through it that bisects the sphere and one of them, joined with the first point also keeps all the points divided equally between the two hemispheres. Keep rotating and repeating. Now how do we know we can reach all the points this way? Another way of thinking of the rotation is actually shrinking the sphere. I don't know how to say this precisely but we choose to shrink the sphere symmetrically about the plane that bisects the hemispheres with equal points on each side. We shrink until another points lies on the plane of bisection. Then we turn slightly to release the first point from the plane of bisection and only one point, the new point lies on the plane of bisection. Then we continue to shrink the sphere until a new point hits the plane. It seems to me that because of topology and the nature of the sphere so long as we always release the original point to the same side of the line of longitude, a new point will hit the new plane of bisection. It is the equivalent of saying in rotational logic that if I have points scattered on an X-Y plane, and I pass a line across the plane in any direction except parallel to the line, that that line will touch all the points. Provided that line moves both along a line and then in the opposite direction. The nature of a closed sphere provides that the line doesn't have to move one direction and then another but all the points can be joined topologically to the other points on a sphere in two directions. One more thought that occurred to me from thinking about this problem is the nature clockwise or CCW rotation. There is nothing in a sphere that would indicate what direction it should rotate. And every time we release point from the plane of symmetry to find a new plane of symmetry we need to release that point in the same direction. But that direction has no indication from the nature of the shape at present, only our memory of the previous action keeps us on track. I know that nobody actually cares, but I haven’t watched the video yet (I paused it so that I could think for a bit) and I think that I might have come with a solution to the problem:

Let’s prove, that if the three points in the plane are not collinear, then the
line rotating about the pivot will stop three times in the same cycle. Let’s assume this statement is false. Then, when a line starts to rotate, it covers every single space in the plane that does not belong to a line between the pivot and the second point. If the third point is not collinear with the other two, then it lays in the space outside of the upper-mentioned line between the two points. If we have a condition, that a line stops when it meets the other point, then, if it covers every single space outside of the between-point line, it MUST encounter the third point (since the third point does not belong to that line). This leads us to an idea, that the line will stop as many times, as the number of elements in the set is (the point does not become a pivot some times in a row, if the pivot is not the only one in the plane; the fact, that if the third point is not collinear to the others, then the line MUST stop at that point). And, if the process continues indefinitely, each point of the set will be encountered by the line infinitely many times.

Long story short. Clever solution: put the line in the middle so there's an equal number of points on each side. If it's odd this works more easily. Every time you hit a point, the number on each side of the line stays constant, so after a 180 degree rotation it has to be on the same point it started on or else there would be different numbers on each side. And after 180 degrees, everything must have switched sides of the line, and since the only way to change sides of the line is to be touched, everything was touched by the line. When it's an even number, you choose a point so that there's one more on one side, we'll call that side A (which is continuously defined relative to the line as the line rotates). After rotating 180 degrees, the line has to have shifted to one point over toward where side A was originally so that there will still be one more point on side A now, and since the initial and final points were clearly touched (and all the others switched sides) all must have been touched. And then you can see the line will go back to its oriignal position after another 180 in order to ensure side A still has one more point in it. Thus the cycle continues and every point is struck infinitely many times.

There exists another easy solution:
Select the largest convex closure possible from S, and label remainder S'. Select the largest convex closure from S', call the remainder S'' and so on.


The line must pass through all consecutive closures, and must have at least 2 members of the innermost closure as its first pivot or to its right.



Additionally, the innermost set, S(nth prime), ought to be divided by the line (if it has 2 or 3 members), or, if it has 1 member, have this member as its pivot, while satisfying the constraints above.


This ensures that the sweeping line is "trapped" within the innermost closure. In order to sweep out a full 180 degrees, or any higher number of degrees, the line must sweep out the entire area of the innermost closure at least once (easy to show). This means that any points within are swept infinitely many times, that all points on the closure are swept, and that all points outside the innermost closure are all swept infinitely many times.

I started thinking the condition for a windmill to hit all points infinitely many times would be more general than the one presented in this solution. After some refinement I think it is. Though the argument gets a bit more complex than what's needed to solve the problem as stated. But I fleshed this out anyway.

For simplicity we admit the notion of a slope of infinity, which is the slope of a vertical line. So the set of all slopes is R + infty, which we hand-wavy regard as possessing the topology of a circle. Every pair of points has a well-defined and unique slope. Let L be the subset of slopes that do NOT correspond to the slope of a pair of points. L is composed of a finite number of connected components.

For each point P in S and each slope t in L define the t-depth of P to be the smaller of the number of the points on either side of the line with slope t passing through P. It's clear the t-depth of any point is constant on each component of L. Every point has a maximal t-depth that's about half the number of points minus 1. Define the depth of a point P to be the minimum of its t-depth over all t in L. The depth of a point P is roughly the number of successive convex hulls you'd have to remove from S in order for P to be in the convex hull of the remaining points.

To guarantee every point is a pivot infinitely many times the starting point doesn't matter. All that matters is that for the point P you pick, you start with an initial slope t such that the t-depth of P is at least the maximal depth taken over all the points in S. This could be far from dividing the other points into two equal-sized sets

For instance, if S is composed of 8 points whose coordinates are all signed combinations of (+/-1, +/-1) and (+/-0.9, +/-0.9). The maximal depth is 1. Your starting point could be the point (1,1) but you have to choose a starting line slope that, at least, separates one of the two adjacent big-square vertices from the rest of the points. Such as a slope of 100. So the line always divides the 7 non-pivot points into a set of 6 and 1, but still hits every point every full rotation because every point has a direction that contains at most 1 other point of S.
Wouldn't it be easier to graph a circle, select a finite amount of points to that circle to represent S, and make sure that the line P would be a tangent to the original circle?

In case anyone wants to know the solution:


Choose a coordinate system so that all points in S have distinct x-coordinates. Number the points Pi=(xi,yi) of S by increasing x-coordinates: x1<x2<...<xN.


In order to divide the set S into two halves, define n so that N=2n+1+d where d=0 for an odd number of points and d=1 for an even number of points.


Start the "windmill" process with the line L going vertically through the point P{n+1}. Attach a down-up direction to this line so that we can color all points as follows: Points to the left of L (with lower x-coordinates) are blue, the pivot point on L is white and point to the right of L (with higher x-coordinates) are red. We have now $n$ blue points, one white point and n+d red points.


After processing the "windmill" by 180 degrees, the line L goes vertically up-down. Now, points with lower x-coordinates are to the right of L and colored red; points with higher x-coordinates are to the left of L and colored blue.


Note that at each pivot exchange, the old pivot point enters the same side of L where the new pivot point came from. This means that throughout the "windmill" process, the number of blue points and the number of red points stay constant, respectively: We still have n blue points, one white point and n+d red points. This means that the current pivot point is P{n+d}.


Note that all blue and all red points changed their color from the start of the "windmill" process. This implies that every point was a pivot at some stage of the rotation.


For every 180 degrees of "windmill" rotation, the same argument applies: all colored points must change their color and hence be a pivot at some stage. Infinitely many rotations imply infinitely many color changes. This completes the proof.

It took me about an hour, but I was able to find a different solution: there are 3 types of shapes that can be made from the points. A line, a polygon with only positive angles, and a polygon with at least one negative angle. The first two will always cycle through all of the points, regardless of the starting point. The last requires discretion on the starting point, demanding The first point to be at one of the negative angles.
The reason for this is that if you split the windmill line at the pivot, only one half of the line will hit points unless there exists a single negative angle. You know you aren't stuck in a positive angled polygon cycle if this is the case. Therefore, just having a single negative angle puts you in an endless cycle without missing points.

As a graphics programmer: I saw the question and the opening animation (up to 2:40) and went: "Isn't this just a triangle mesh?"
So going from Triangle mesh, we can show, easily, that any rotation in a direction from any point will move you to one and only one different pair of points on the mesh. (1,2)->(2,3)->(3,1) for example, and the opposite rotation would do the opposite.
We can easily show that for any given mesh, that splitting the mesh in twain (either by placing the line between two points such that half the points are on either side (in a 4 point mesh, (1,3) placing 2 and 4 on opposing sides for example) , or placing the line through a point such that each side has half the points (in a three point mesh, (points: (X axis), (1x,1y) ) thus placing 2 and three on opposing sides) we can use basic graph theory to split the point pairs into nodes on a directed topographical map and then we can use basic topology to show that the graph must be 1) directed (each pair of points, in a certain order implies only one next pair of points) 2) cyclical (there is some path in the graph that repeats) and 3) that the path that starts with the first Point or pair of points as described above implies all nodes that, together, touch each point at least once before cycling.

Well, in making a video game anyway.

So I have this non-square procedural generator I'm developing and planning, and as part of that the landscape is generated first with rock that are immovable and doodads that can be removed. Then I generate a city on top of that with buildings with doors. The buildings are on a blueprint with a footprint around each building that must not intersect an immovable rock and must be X number of units away from the nearest building and x number of units away from the nearest immovable rock. The script spawns the blueprint on the possible coordinates of a pre-placed mountains, and then moves the buildings away from the rocks to not intersect.

Okay, that's the scatter plot.

Now each building has a doorway that leads to a parametric path to all other doorways on the local map (so NPCs generated within each building can spawn and travel to all other buildings on the map with no pathing errors.) And most towns have a central well, or common "town center" which all paths lead to. (the paths are just splines that project a dirt or flagstone texture onto the terrain and allow for a navmesh for npcs to prioritize.)

Each building has a rotation on a pivot, and that pivot needs to, in certain town types (the circular caravan camp with tents all facing inwards comes to mind) match the pivot of the other doorways, so they all more or less point to one another.

No building that spawns may intersect the path to another building, either. So if a building is placed on the map, displaced by terrain, then moved into the path of another building, moved further away from the central pivot of the town footprint. And if no further point is reachable, that was an error, so I culled the building and removed it from the formlist of building types available in this town (and if the town generated was meant to have a farmer, everyone in this town would stave. :p Oops.)

So that created this problem. I had points in space scattered across a map, where no three building are in a line and the pivot must be capable of rotating to face the common center of all other doorways. When did it know when to stop trying to rotate? It could be infinite! So I just solved it by constraining the rotations to 124 degrees off axis on te third turn and giving up in that configuration.

The answer:

Suppose that |S|=2n+1. Consider any line that separates S into equal halves; this line is unique given its direction and contains some point T belongs to S. Consider the windmill starting from this line. When the line has made a rotation of 180° it returns to the same location but the orange side becomes blue and vice versa. So, for each point there should have been a moment where it appeared as a pivot, as this is the only way for the point to pass from one side to the other.

Now suppose that |S|=2n. Consider a line having n-1 and n points on the two sides; it contains some point T. Consider the windmill starting from this point. After having made a rotation of 180°, the windmill line contains a different point R, and each point different from T and R has changed the color of its side. So, the windmill should have passed through all the points.

Interestingly I came at this in a totally different way, without assigning any numbers. I suspect there's a hole in what I did somewhere. If anyone is up for reading through it and pointing out issues, I'd very much appreciate it:

1. The line will turn forever since we've defined no state where it stops turning.
2. Once the line has turned 180deg from its starting orientation, its ends will have swept the entire space of the plane.
3. For any finite set of points, the set of all ways of traversing some or all of those points must be itself finite. Thus traversing the points infinitely (as our line will do, per point 1) necessitates that the path of the traverse will settle into a loop which it repeats infinitely.

We can also show that not only must the path settle into this loop, it begins on the loop:

4. Since as specified, no three points lie on the same line, there is only ever one 'next' point for the turning line to hit. It will never strike two at the same time.
5. Mirroring S gives a dual space S' which behaves under clockwise rotation exactly as S would behave under anticlockwise rotation.
6. Taking 4 & 5 together, there is only ever one previous point for the line to have hit, thus it must not merely settle into a loop, but begin on it.

7. From the above, we now know that for any set of points S, there is at least a subset of S (subS) for which the criteria of every point being hit infinitely is true.

8. When completing one traverse of subS, by which we mean both arriving back at the starting point P, and with the line l in in its starting orientation, we know both that l has turned 360deg, and that the point of rotation has traced a path through every point in subS. In the same way that the line rotating 360deg about a single point will sweep the plane (twice), in this case the line has swept all of the plane with the exception of the subspace bounded by the points in subS.
9. From this we conclude that for any traversable loop, no points can lie outside the path of the loop and not themselves belong to the loop.

This still leaves us with the possibility of a point inside the bounds of the loop which isn't touched. Let's clear those guys up.

10. If one or more points exists within the subspace bounded by subS, and it doesn't belong to subS, we choose one such point as our new starting point P' and begin again.
11. As P' lay inside the bounds of subS, all points in subS lay outside P'. By statement 9 we therefore know that any traversable loop from P' also includes all points in subS.

12. Since there are only finite points, and the interior of the subspace bounded by the new loop from P' is itself a subspace of the original subspace subS belonging to our first choice of P, we can iterate this method finitely many times until we settle onto a point for which no other points lie within the subspace bounded by a legal loop from that point, which it concert with statement 9 tells us that a loop from that point must take in every point, and, by statement 3, that loop occurs infinitely, thus solving our original question.

(What makes me think there must be some mistake here is that the orientation of l through P doesn't even seem to matter by this solution.)

This feels like a problem that can be solved with induction. I wrote my proof below. Not sure if it’s right or not. Wouldn’t surprise me if the proving n+1 case is wrong

Base case: given 2 dots and a line that rotated around each dot until to crosses another dot, placing the line on any dot would cause it to rotate around each dot indefinitely

Assume: for n points, there’s a way of placing a line through an initial point that would cause it to rotate around each point repeatedly

If there’s n+1 points, then there exists two scenarios: putting the line on point within n eventually hits the new point, or it won’t hit the new point.

If placing the line on the point within n cause it to hit the +1 point, it will then hit a point within n causing the cycle to repeat indefinitely as per our assumption.

If it won’t hit the +1 point, then if we place the line on the +1 point, then it will eventually hit a point p that is within n, causing it to rotate through each point as per our assumption, and thus must rotate 360 degrees, meaning it will also rotate around p. Since the +1 point hits p when rotating, that means p, or a point within n that p hits, can hit the +1 point when rotating as well, which causes the cycle to repeat. Thus our assumption must be true for n+1 points

If our assumption is true for n+1 points, it must be true for n points

I learned while still young to look for symmetries or invariants in problems. I wasn't told to do so (well, until many years later). It just "seemed right"; it made it easier to simplify a problem, to make a meaningful picture, and usually lead to some key idea at the heart of the problem. Plus, I often felt a sense of beauty or wonder when I found it; it was the Easter egg hidden in the bushes of a thorny problem. But I didn't really think too deeply about WHY they were both beautiful and powerful. Why are symmetries the holy grails of deep physics? Why do we feel satisfaction at seeing the windmill always divide the field in half, no matter where it moves to?

One thought I had is that it's like entropy, or why there is an arrow of time: out of all the possible configurations of a system, what are the chances that it would just keep returning to the same point? The fallen egg never reassembles into a whole egg; it's theoretically possible, but statistically preposterous. If you see it do so in a video, you say aha! There has to be something unusual going on here, that caused this, for example that they played the video backwards. So could the same be true for invariants in math? They're unusual, they surely are not a random fluke, so must get at something important?

But that doesn't seem to me the whole story. Other configurations could be picked other than "these two things are equal", which statistically are just as special, say a 2:1 resonance. They're not as beautiful, and they don't stand out as obviously, but otherwise would work as well. Something to do with conservation of a quantity telling us what is unique and fundamental about a system? I'm wondering what others might think (or know) about this...

Here is a somewhat different angle to think about this; perhaps it is the same logic, not sure...


Let's start with 5 points, such that one of them is inside a tetragon formed by the others (if all points form a polygon, the solution is trivial). Let's now connect the outer dots by choosing one of them as the pivot so that all points are to one side of the pivot. This way, we are guaranteed to miss the inner point. Now we need to prove that whenever we start with a line inside the tetragon - in this case through the inner point - the line can never get outside. For this, we can use the conservation of right/left or up/down partitions. We can now build up an "onion" model, by which we find the outermost polygon, the second outermost, etc., until we are at the center. We can now pick any center point and angle and are guaranteed to touch all outer and inner points when rotating, because the lines never get outside any layer of polygon, hence a full rotation touches all points.

I think I have a shorter proof.

Define a "state" as a triplet of a point P together with an orientation (clockwise or counterclockwise) and an angle range, on which the straight line through P meets no other points.
The set of all states is finite, since there are only finitely many points. One step in the windmill process is a one-to-one mapping between the states, i.e. a permutation "phi" on the set of states.Permutations on finite sets have finite order (elementary group theory), therefore there is a number n such that phi^n=e the neutral element of the permutation group. Therefore every n steps, the point is visited again (even in the same state). It must therefore be visited infinitely many times.

A system with a finite number of states must loop eventually. If a state is not part of a loop, then there must be some state within a loop that has multiple direct predecessors, and in a reversible system each state can only have one direct predecessor. Therefore, all states in a reversible system with a finite number of states are part of a loop.

I paused the video when the problem was first posted and tried to solve it myself. Took me about 10 minutes to come up with a workable proof. If I had to write it down it would take a little longer, but still not too long.
Thing is, my proof was completely different. Started with a similar process but I went in a completely different direction:

When there's only two points then it's trivial. Every possible line is going to alternate between both points. Expand to 3 points. Since they aren't colinear they must form a triangle. So now you're effectively got 2 possible starting lines. From one point, either it goes outside the triangle or it goes between the other 2 points through the middle of the triangle. Coincidentally, both of those lines still cycle through all 3 points. When you get to 4 is when it starts getting complicated. Now your 4-sided figure can be convex (in which case any line still works) or one of the points can make a concavity in which case a line around the outside will miss that point, but any line through the middle, even if it doesn't start on that point directly, will eventually get to it, and to all the other 3.
(At this point I started off on an incorrect path so I'll skip to the part where I came back to the proof that actually works). As we keep adding points our N-Sided figure expands to become larger and eventually approaches a circle. Well, a really warped, irregular loop that's not necessarily circular but still conceptually similar. So let's draw an actual circle. But S had to be finite, so we can just make it a ring of discrete points. If we include the center point and draw a line to any point of the ring, no 3 points can be colinear (initial conditions) so the opposite side of the ring won't have a point there, and you get a special instance of the set S where all the points form a ring with one additional point at the exact center. It's not hard to visualize a windmill like through that center point and see that it's going to hit a periphery point, break off the center and move to hit a point on the opposite side. Then it breaks off the near side point and moves to either hit the center again or to hit the next point on the ring. So consider both cases: if it hits the center point then you effectively return to the initial position and it continues indefinitely. If it hits a ring point instead then it'll switch and go to the next far side ring point, switch again, and possibly hit the center point again. But is it possible that it will keep hitting ring points and never come back to the center? Well, no. In order for that to happen each time it moves along the far side of the ring it has to go farther along the arc than it does along the near side. Repeat this enough times and the line has to catch up with itself and get to where it's at two adjacent points, leaving no other option than to move back to the center point again. So here we have proved that in the special case of S where you have a ring of points and the center point there will always be a solution.
Now consider taking one point of that ring and moving it out some arbitrary distance from the ring. Does this change the action of the windmill? The windmill moves from the preceding point toward where the ring point would be and again we have two cases. Either it's pivoting on the center point, in which case distance doesn't matter because the angle of the line will stay the same, or it's pivoting from a ring point, so that it might hit another ring point first. But we've already seen that it has to hit that center point eventually, so it will then proceed on to hit the extended point as well. So now we see that extending the distance of points out from the ring still allows for a solution.
All that remains is to show that for ANY set S, if you pick a point somewhere near the middle (doesn't have to be the exact center, just far enough in to avoid the possibility of moving only around the outside), then draw line segments from that point to each other point in S. Now you have drawn a starburst figure. Pick a distance less than or equal to the smallest of those segments and trim each segment to that length. Now you've defined a ring that is functionally equivalent to S when some of the ring points are extended out. Since no three points can be collinear this will be possible for every set S and thus we have a solution possible for every possible S.

Beautiful video, as always! I personally started out closely following the video, but then took it in another direction.

As noted in the video, there's this vague concept that comes up pretty quickly of some point being 'inside' others, and hence never being able to be hit by the line (in some starting cases).

So, I started defining things like Boundaries: B0 the largest convex polygon that can be created using points from the set as vertices. Then removing those points to find the next boundary B1, and so on. Defining 'depth' as the number of nested polygons/boundaries needed to exhaust the set.

The idea being that you need to start, or somewhere along the road hit, one of the points of the innermost boundary if you want a shot at hitting all the points. Otherwise, you might just skip along a higher level boundary like with the triangle and a point inside of it (when starting outside the triangle).

I didn't get to rigorously confirm these ideas. But I wonder if you continue down this line you might not just prove that all point can be hit infinitely many times, but which lines actually do so without having to impose the 50/50 rule used in the video's proof.

So I thnk there are holes in my reasoning, but here's what I'm thinking. Assuming there are finite points (which there have to be if none are colinear), then there will always be an arbitrary point P about which you can draw line L. Denote another line, M, which is set in place to be equal to line L at t=0. Then, for each point in S, there will be a unique angle θ between M and that point and the original pivot. Then, given that there are finite points, line L must pass through each angle θ in a full rotation.

Given arbitrary point N in S and arbitrary θ Φ, with original pivot P, current pivot P':
Case 1: If L hits N while rotating (i.e. N is an element of L, ANG(L, M)=Φ, or PN=L), then the counter on N ticks up and the next point is denoted N.
Case 2: If L is counterclockwise of N when ANG(L, M)=Φ, (i.e. line PN and L are parallel), then denote M'=L. This process is recursive, but given that Φ decreases each rotation (which it would have to given there are no colinear points), and this can occur infinitely many times, at some time t, N must be an element of L.


Then there must be a proof that L returns to the base case M. Not sure how to do that, but I'd argue that something along the lines of Case 2 might work given that ANG(L,M) must be all possible values (0, 2pi] throughout the process.

As an observation, while it's not on the critical path to the solution, the motion of the windmill is reversible, and remains deterministic when reversed, so if it ever enters a loop, that loop has to include the initial position.

The only way to avoid looping is to keep entering new states, where states are defined in such a way that you don't lose important information. For example, each pivot being a single state is too coarse grained, because a single pivot can be followed by any other point as pivot, depending on the line's angle. If you define the states as the pivot point combined with which pair of points the line is between (assuming at least 3 points, but the cases with fewer points are trivial) then you have a finite number of states, but in each state, the next and previous states are still uniquely determined. With a finite number of states, you can't keep entering new states indefinitely, so the process must loop.

Therefore, each point must either become the pivot infinitely many times, or never. The trick then is to show you can find a suitable starting condition to visit each point at least once...

Here's my take on it:
Let there be n points. Consider the n cases where the line is vertical through a point. Since the line will always eventually be vertical, any cycle must include one of these n cases, thus there can at most be n distinct cycles. In each of the cases the distribution of points on either side is different, but invariant throughout the cycle, thus the cases are from different cycles, (We'll separate left-right parities for simplicity), meaning there are at least n distinct cycles. Therefore we have exactly n distinct cycles identified by their left-right point distribution. Now consider that it is possible to draw a line through any point separating the n points into the same left-right distribution. All of these states must exist in the exact same cycle, since the distribution is the same. Therefore it forms a cycle where every point is visited, and since it's a cycle they will be visited infinitely often.

7:54 For the very first time, I actually came up with the idea of splitting the set into 2 parts(as well as other facts which came from this idea) when I was taking a stab at the problem before watching the video, so I managed to figure out that a line is in the "middle" when it divides the set in half, and why it stays like that. Since this is the first time I've actually managed to solve something before seeing any part of the video, I just have to share how I found this out, I started off just picking a few points and just drawing a "snapshot" of the system at each pivot point. Then, I decided to record how the line splits the set in each snapshot, without caring to label each side. When recording the splits on the second snapshot, I saw that most of the points were still on the same side, with only one point which had been replaced. Then, I did it again except this time making the line into a sort of directional line(I called it a "vector line") to record the points on the left and right sides of the line, mainly so I would have some definitive idea of which side the points are on. Then, I found that when going from one snapshot to the next one, one point was removed from a particular side(which is the point which the line pivots on in the next snapshot), and another point was added(which is the point which the line had pivoted on before). I didn't actually get much further than this, and decided to watch the rest of the video. When I got to the part where you asked what is the "middle", and if one can guarantee that the line stays in that middle if it starts off there, I thought about it for a little bit, and made the definition of the middle be when a line divides the set in half(or at least divides it as good as possible). With that I found out that since the points on a particular side gain one point, and lose another point, then the number of points on each side must not change(ie. n + 1 - 1 = n). Therefore, when the line starts in the middle, it will remain in the middle


TL;DR, I discovered that the points on each side of the line are only replaced by another point when it changes its pivoting point. Then, during the video I used that discovery to figure out what definition of a "line in the middle" to use, and proved that the number of points on each side of a line remains constant as it switches pivot points. Thus proving that a line in the middle stays in the middle

I think we don't actually have the data to show that it's a genuinely hard problem, in a general sense. We have the data to show that this specific group of people trained to think of mathematics in specific ways, for this specific type of test, did not think of the problem in these ways, and there might be a reason they didn't, despite the solution being, from an outside perspective, relatively intuitive. The ability to solve hard mathematical problems - in the certain mathematically inabstract ways that are trained into these students - doesn't mean that the question was necessarily difficult in an inherent way. To label every layperson who sees this problem and who visualizes the problem more simply and from a less mathematically strict perspective a "fool" is foolish. Many times over it's been demonstrated, across many fields, that outside perspectives are able to see problems and tackle them more easily, because a focused study can lead to preconceptions and uniform ways of thinking. Of course, maybe it IS a hard question. That's possible. But to think all people fools who might consider this an intuitive proof is kind of ironically a bit foolish to say. So our points S are part of a greater group of points G. G is infinite and describes every point of the plane. My goal now is to mark every point of G as a point of the plane, it doesnt matter if a point is marked more than once, in fact most of them will be marked more than once. To do this i use a line that rotates clockwise (the windmill). A point of G is marked as part of the plane, if the line hits it. In the simplest case with one center of rotation you just have to rotate 360° to mark the whole plane. In general you can say that the line needs to rotate at least 360° to mark the whole plane.



Now i imagine every point of S as the center of its own rotating line. This gives every point of S its own "colored circle of rotation". In addition to that, all of those circles overlap perfectly, every point of one circle is also a point of every other circle. Thus it should be possible to mark the whole plane via the sum of part-rotations of the single rotation circles of the points of S. So if every point of G is marked, every point of S is also marked, because S is part of G. And because that sum adds up to the whole plane, there is no fear of getting into a loop after a while, where some points are spared, because then you would no longer mark the whole plane, which you did at first, leading to a contradiction.

I paused the video to think about it myself, and I didn't quite put the entire solution together, but I did find an interesting reformulation of the problem: imagine the whole system of points rotating around some origin, so that the "arm" of the windmill is always horizontal. If you graph the "height" of each point as a function of the angle, it gives a sine curve with an amplitude and phase determined by its position. The height of the arm is always equal to the height of one of the points, but it will switch whenever another point's height is equal to it. So you can represent the height of the arm by tracing along the sine curves, switching from one curve to another every time the new one crosses your path.

For me at least it was a lot easier to visualize finding a zigzag path between these sine curves than it was to reason about the original geometric formulation.

This was a very enjoyable puzzle! I came up with a slightly different reasoning, which also gives a stronger result (explained below). However, the thumbnail spoiled a major part of the solution - without the thumbnail, I would've probably needed to experiment more with the problem before finding the invariant. Just something to be considered in the future when designing thumbnails ;).

So, what I did was the following. Denote n to be the number of points in S. For a line passing through a single pivot point in S, denote L and R to be the number of points on the left and right, respectively. First, I did the following observations (same as in the video, just slightly generalized):
1. During a windmill, L-R is invariant.
2. For any pivot in S there exists a line such that
a) if n is odd, L-R = 0
b) if n is even, L-R = 1
3. If we fix the angle of the line, L-R gives a different value for every pivot.

This is where my reasoning diverges. Let b = 0, if n is odd, and b = 1, if n is even. Start at any pivot with a line such that L-R=b. By 2, for any pivot there exists some angle for which L-R=b. By 3, for any angle, if there exists a point in S which gives L-R=b, such a point is unique. Therefore, for any pivot in S, when the line is at an angle such that L-R=b for that pivot, we know that the line must have that point as a pivot. As each angle is visited infinitely many times during a windmill, the claim is proved.

This solution actually also tells, how many times a point in S is a pivot during a single round of windmill when we fix L-R=d. For a fixed pivot, we say that two lines are equivalent if they share they share the sets of points on the left and the right side of them. A slightly different approach: Look at a triangle defined by three of the points in your set. Define the line to be "inside" the triangle if it EVER passes through the interior of the triangle (not just the boundary).


Observe that as the line rotates, if it is inside a triangle, it will always be inside that triangle. This can be seen in the following way. If the line is rotating about a point that is not a vertex of the triangle, then in order to pass through the interior of the triangle, the line must pass between two vertices of the triangle. Rotating such a line a small amount about any point a sufficiently small amount doesn't cause it to jump over a vertex. If the line is rotating about a vertex of the triangle, and is inside the triangle, then it must pass through the other two vertices. A small rotation of the line does not change this. Finally, observe that if the line is rotating about a vertex of the triangle, and contacts another vertex, then the rotation of the line about the new vertex will immediately swing the line into the interior of the triangle. (This last bit takes a little thought, but is not hard to see).


Similarly, if the triangle is "outside" a triangle, it will never become inside that triangle, through similar observations.


If a line is inside a triangle, it will pivot around all three vertices of that triangle at least once in a half turn.


The line will pivot around a point if it passes through a triangle that contains that point as a vertex.


To make the line pass through all points, you find a set of triangles that have every point as a vertex, that have a common internal point. If the line passes through this common point, it will rotate about every vertex.


To see that there is such a collection of triangles with a common internal point, find the smallest circle that contains every point in your set. To be smallest, there must be a point on the circumference, pick one and call it x. Draw a line through x and tangent to the circle. Pivot that line about x (clockwise or counterclockwise, it doesn't matter) until it first intersects another point in the set, and call that point y. For all other points in your set, z, z not equal to x and y, draw a triangle xyz. All of these triangles have a common edge, x-y, and therefore intersecting all of them will give you an interior point near edge x-y (finite intersections of open sets are open).


Choosing any point as your initial pivot, and orienting the line to pass through this common intersection point will cause the line to pivot through all points at least once.




Finally, as an aside, if you imagine that you are performing this process on a sphere, then you can imagine that each set of three points determines multiple triangles (some of which pass through infinity). I believe (without proof) that you can use some clever geometry to figure out the precise order in which the line pivots around points.

A line is infinite. And I'm not sure if the plane is also infinitely large, but if they are both infinite, then they are equally large. The important part is that at any point in time the line spans the whole length of the plane.

The line only ever spins clockwise, so it will need to turn 360 degrees at some point, regardless of the pivot. Since the line always covers the whole length of the plane, this means that every point in the plane is touched at least once during a full rotation.

(Edited) A few people ask "but what is the formal solution?". Take a look at this writeup, which you'll find is essentially the same as the video. It would get you full marks on the test: https://artofproblemsolving.com/wiki/index.php?title=2011_IMO_Problems/Problem_2

The fact that an argument doesn't reference equations and sets doesn't necessarily make it incomplete. Sure, you could explicitly define what words like "left" and "right" refer to by defining such and such cross product with such and such parameterization of the line, but for most readers, it wouldn't actually remove any ambiguity. The purpose of formality is to make all the terms used unambiguous to all readers, not to dress up the language to involve sufficiently many symbols. If you understood this video, you understood the full solution.
